THURSDAY, JULY 5, 1906.
PRESS IN WAR TIME

The question of the Press in time of war has now passed into its penultimate stage.The Prime Minister has taken it under his official wing and, lhas placed it upon the list of Government measures with which he hopes to deal next year. That is a decision (says the "Morning Post") upon which both the Press and the Government are to be congratulated the Press for voluntarily raising the question and in a sense asking to be restrained generally where restraint is essential to the national interest and the Government for taking the matter up in a straightforward and effective fashion. Mr. Arthur Lee, who as an ex Army officer, our Military Attache at Washington during the Spanish American War, and a Civil Lord of the Admiralty under the late Government, probably knows the ins and outs of the subject as well as any man in the House recently asked the Prime Minister whether his attention had been called to the recent conference of newspaper proprietors and editors, "at which there was a unanimous expression of opinion in favor of restricting or controlling the dissemination of news in time of war,” and what action he proposed to take in consequence. The Prime Minister answered that the matter was being considered by the Committee of Imperial Defence and that he hoped to bring in a Bill dealing with it early next year. Mr. Lee very properly asked whether the Bill might not be introduced this session so that the Press might have an opportunity of studying its provisions at leisure. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman replied that there were means of communicating with the Press other than by introducing a Bill in the House. We take this to me that nothing in the way of hasty legislation is contemplated sad that the Press will either be consulted during the period of drafting the Bill or that the Bill when completed will be referred to the Press for criticism and suggestions. In either case the Government is plainly prepared to collaborate with the Press in the work of formulating a measures that will secure the maximum of safety to the State with the minimum of interference with legitimate journalistic activities. It was for this purpose that the Conference of June 21 authorised the Sub-Committee of the Newspaper Society to add to its numbers men with special knowledge of the points at issue and to consider any Bill that might be drafted. The Government need not hesitate to treat the enlarged Sub-Committee as fully representative of the Press as a whole. We would suggest that the right course to take is for the Government to draft the sort of Bill it would like to passed, and for the Sub Committee of the Newspaper society to bring its provisions as far as possible into harmony with the opinions expressed at the recent conference, and, if necessary to call a further conference. The resultant would probably be a measure prohibiting in time of war and when war is imminent the unauthorized publications as news of naval and military movements. If there were incorporated in such a measure the guarantee which the Committee of Imperial Defence but already informally offered-guarantee, for instances that it would only be invoked in the event of an imminent war with a first class Power, that it would come to operate automatically on the conclusion of peace, and that its administration would be in civil hands-the Press would, we believe, be found ready to accept it. In the long run the three interests of journalism and the true interests of the nation must be identical. The Press cannot gain where the nation loses, and that the nation s tands to lose heavily by the unrestricted publication of news in time of war is very evident. Journalists desire to relieve their profession from its liability to become at any moment a source of peril to the country.

A Brute in Human Form.

A terrible story is published by a Cairo contemporary which shows that Egypt can boast some imported savages in every way equal to the Manoufiah product. It is stated that a Greek servant girl who had been employed for several years at the house of one Ch. Callicopoulo, a Cairo bootmaker, was recently accused by her master of the theft of money and jewels. To extort a confession her scoundrelly employer beat the girl most cruelly, kicked her, poured boiling oil over her hands and wrists, and finally tied her up and tortured her by applying boiling eggs to the armpits! These last tortures inflicted such excruciating pain that the poor girl died of the shock. The Greek Consulate has ordered Dr. Lambros to enquire into the affair and has refused to listen to certain medical evidence obtained by Callicopoulo, who will be tried here before M. Scotidie. We are informed by the Greek Consulate that the name of the victim is Dandris. She died after three days of agony. A warrant has been issued for the arrest of Callicopoulo, who will be tried at the Criminal Assinas at Alexandria in December. M. Vernitki Hellenic, Vice Colonel, is investigating the case. The sum alleged to have been stolen is 300 pounds, and it is said that the loss of it turned the brain of Callicopoulos, who is well known among the Hellenic colony of Cairo.

div.head: DENISHWAI. M. P.'S SENTIMENTALISM. QUESTIONS IN THE HOUSE. OPINION IN ENGLAND. (Gazette's Special Service)

div.p: Those who are best able to judge Egypt's needs as a result of many years' experience of the country strongly deprecate the remarks which have been made by certain irresponsible individuals in the House of Commons during the last few days in connection with the verdict in the Danishwi affair. The utterances are looked upon as mere Little Englandiam and as having the savour of a desire for self-notoriety.

It is sincerely hoped by all who have the real welfare of Egypt at heart that the public at home will not be led away by the excessive deal of persons who are simply desirous of making political capital out of this unfortunate incident.

As an instance of how little the customs of the country are understood here, the wailing of the women at the time of the execution has been made much of and has produced a great effect on the feelings of individuals who are unaware that it is the custom for this to occur in all cases of death, and had no other significance at Denishwai.

I learn that the action of the Egyptian authorities has met with the entire approval of both the Europeans and the educated natives as being absolutely necessary to check any undue lawlessness and brutality on the part of the lower class of natives, who are not yet sufficiently advanced in the path of civilisation to appreciate unjust leniency.
It is considered to be most unlikely that the home Government will interfere in the matter.

In the House of Commons last Wednesday, Mr. Dillon asked the Prime Minister, in the absence of the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he had been made aware of the fact that that morning four Egyptians were sentenced to death by the special court in connexion with the unfortunate affair at Denishwai, and whether he could undertake to obtain a respite of the sentence until the Foreign Minister had had an opportunity of personally examining the evidence given betro the tribunal.

The Prime Minister: I have not heard anything of the circumstance referred to by the hon. member, but I am sure we can trust to the discretion and humanity of my right hon. friend the Foreign Secretary (Sir Edward Grey) to see that everything is done that may be necessary. (Cheers.)

On the following day, Mr. Dillon asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he had yet received any detailed information as to the aircumstarces which led to the affray: whether any of the natives were killed or injured; if any natives were killed or injured, would the British officers who took part in the affray be tried; whether the pigeons shot on these occasions were tame or wild pigeons ; whether occasions were tame or wild pigeons ; whether pigeon shooting in the neighbourhood of villages was a legal occupation in Egypt; whether in this instance the permission of the headman of the village had been obtained by the officers before they commenced to shoot ; what were the special grounds on which the Agent and Consul of Great Britain demanded that the accused Egyptians in this case should be sent for trial before the Special Tribunal; and whether there was any appeal from the Special Tribunal before which the Egyptians were to be tried.

Sir E. Grey.--I cannot answer all the details of the hon. member's question. I do not know whether any native was killed or injured, but our information is that the British officers, when they were attacked by the natives, gave up their guns and refused to fire in self-defence (hear, hear), and if any natives were killed, it was clearly not by the action of the British officers. When the report appeared in the Press yesterday, I telegraphed to know what the sentences were, and what were the facts established at the trial, saying that it was desirable we should know them before any death sentences were executed. The information I have received is as follows -The sentences were as stated in the Press, except that, I think, only two men were sentenced to penal servitude for life, whereas the Press stated four. With regard to the trial, the prisoners were defended by three of the best-known native advocates, who had a full hearing. The Court was unanimous as regards the prisoners found guilty, and the evidence clearly established premeditation and concerted actions. Thirty one of the prisoners were acquitted and 21 were found guilty. The Court expressed its opinion that the British officers had behaved with extreme forbearance and self-restraint. (Hcar, hear.) The chief attack took place after they had given up their guns and was persisted in with great brutality. I am also informed that, in the opinion of Judge Bond and Mr. Hayter, the Acting Judicial Adviser, both members of the Court, the first six prisoners would undoubtedly have been found guilty of murder by a British jury. The Special Court was composed of the Egyptian Minister for Foreign Affairs, who has had several years' experience in the Ministry of Justice in the absence of the latter ; Mr. Bond, Vice-President of the Native Court of Appeal, whose position is practically that of Dord Chief Justice ; Fethy Bey, President of the Cairo Native Court; Mr. Hayter, Action Judicial Adviser, formerly a Judge in the Sudan, and Colonel Ludlew, Officiating Judge Advocate.
